refnamediv.refpurpose: dynamic execution of SQL returning state and result set

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function provides dynamic SQL capabilities in Virtuoso PL. The first argument is an arbitrary SQL statement, which may contain parameter placeholders. The function returns as output parameters a SQL state, error message, column metadata and result set rows if the statement is a select.
A stored procedure can be invoked by exec but a procedure's result set will not be received in the rows output parameter but rather sent to the client.

refsect2.para: A varchar containing arbitrary SQL using ?'s for parameter markers.

refsect2.title: state
refsect2.para: An output parameter of type varchar set to the 5 character SQL state if the exec resulted an error. Not set if an error is not present.

refsect2.title: message
refsect2.para: An output parameter of type varchar set to SQL error message associated with the error. Not set if an error is not present.

refsect2.title: params
refsect2.para: A vector containing the parameters for the SQL being executed. Element 0 corresponding to first ?, etc.

refsect2.title: maxrows
refsect2.para: The integer maximum number of rows to retrieve in case of a statement returning a result set.

refsect2.title: metadata
refsect2.para: An output parameter of type vector returning the metadata of the statement and its result.

row.entry: An array containing description of each column in the result set (see table below for contents)
An integer 1 indicates that the statement is a select, otherwise it is a DML statement.
Trailing elements may appear, but they should not be used
Column type as an internal type code corresponding, but not equal to ODBC SQL type codes.

refsect2.title: rows
refsect2.para: An output array with one element per result row containing an array with the leftmost column as element 0 and so forth.

refsect2.title: cursor_handle
refsect2.para: The cursor handle for use with related functions.

example.title: Procedure Example
example.para: This stored procedure returns 1 if a given table is empty. An error such as a timeout or deadlock would be reported back to the caller as an exception. Exec always returns, no matter the type of exception. Thus it is also useful as a universal error catcher.
